titleStmt.title: Distributed time-varying output formation tracking for heterogeneous linear multi-agent systems with a nonautonomous leader of unknown input

affiliation.orgName: School of Automation Science and Electrical Engineering, Science and Technology on Aircraft Control Laboratory

analytic.title: Distributed time-varying output formation tracking for heterogeneous linear multi-agent systems with a nonautonomous leader of unknown input

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TAC.2019.2893978, IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON AUTOMATIC CONTROL 1

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper studies the time-varying output formation (TVOF) tracking problems for heterogeneous linear multi-agent systems with a nonautonomous leader on directed topologies, where the dynamics of the agents can be different in the aspects of both parameters and dimensions, and the leader can have unknown control input. A TVOF tracking protocol and a design algorithm are presented using the neighboring interaction. In the proposed protocol, a distributed observer with adaptive updating mechanism is constructed for each follower to asymptotically estimate the state of the leader under the influences of the leader's unknown input firstly. Then, a local formation controller is presented by utilizing the distributed observer, the local state observer and the desired formation vector. Based on the Lyapunov stability theory, it is proved that the expected TVOF tracking can be accomplished by the heterogeneous multi-agent systems in the presence of the leader's unknown input. Furthermore, a continuous TVOF tracking protocol with σ-modification adaptive law is proposed to avoid the large chattering phenomenon.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: F ORMATION control of multi-agent systems, including unmanned aerial vehicles, mobile robotic systems and autonomous underwater vehicles, has received significant research interest in recent years. Formation control has practical potential in many scenarios, such as cooperative source seeking [1], moving target enclosing [2] and surveillance [3]. For large-scale multi-agent systems, compared with centralized coordination approaches, distributed control strategies have less computation cost and higher scalability and flexibility [4].
One research focus of formation problems is to present distributed control protocols for each agent with only neighboring interaction (see, e.g. [5]- [8]).

In many practical applications, besides forming the prescribed formation configuration, the entire multi-agent system should also track the expected reference trajectory. Thus, the formation tracking problems arise, where the followers are required to not only achieve the prescribed formation but also track the expected trajectory generated by a real or virtual leader. In [9]- [12], several distributed formation tracking approaches were presented, where the desired formation configurations were specified by constant vectors. However, in some situations, e.g., moving target enclosing and obstacle avoidance, the multi-agent system should transform the formation configurations in real time to adapt to the requirements of environment and task. Thus, it is more general to consider the time-varying formation tracking case. Based on neighboring information interaction, distributed time-varying formation tracking problems for first-order, nonholonomic, second-order, and general linear multi-agent systems were respectively considered in [13]- [19], where every follower has identical ideal dynamics. However, in some practical scenes, such as the cooperative surveillance using a group of unmanned ground vehicles and unmanned aerial vehicles [20], the dynamics of the agents may be different in the aspects of both parameters and dimensions.

The heterogeneous multi-agent systems cannot be transformed to a compact form by using the Kronecker product, which means that the analysis approaches for homogeneous case in [13]- [19] are no longer directly applicable. Moreover, only using the neighboring relative information feedback cannot realize the expected formation tracking for heterogeneous multi-agent systems, and it is necessary to construct different control structures. For a group of heterogeneous agents, cooperative output regulation problems have received a great deal of attention (see, e.g. [21]- [26]), where a group of subsystems (i.e., the followers) can track the reference trajectory or reject the disturbance generated by an exosystem (i.e., the leader). Based on the output regulation strategies, formation tracking problems for heterogeneous multi-agent systems were investigated in [27]- [29].

It should be pointed out that the exosystem is required to have no control input (i.e., the exosystem is autonomous) in [21]- [29]. In practice, the exosystem should have nonzero control inputs to generate more general reference signals and regulate the expected trajectory in real time. Moreover, if the exosystem denotes a noncooperative target, it is difficult for all the followers to acquire its control input. The consensus tracking problems under the influences of the leader's unknown input were studied in [30]- [33]. Note that the existing consensus approaches in [30]- [33] are applicable to either homogeneous multi-agent systems or undirected graph among followers. The variability of expected formation will cause both the formation information and its derivative in the design and analysis of the protocol, which increases the complexity of formation problems. As far as we know, time-varying formation tracking problems for general linear multi-agent systems on directed graphs with heterogeneous dynamics and a nonautonomous leader are still open.

Inspired by the above facts, this paper focuses on the distributed time-varying output formation (TVOF) tracking problems for heterogeneous linear multi-agent systems under the influences of the leader's unknown input. Compared with the relevant works, the main contributions of the current paper are threefold. First, the expected formation is timevarying and the dynamics of each agent can be heterogeneous in the aspects of both parameters and dimensions. The given formation vectors in [9]- [12] are restricted to be timeinvariant. In [13]- [19], only homogeneous multi-agent systems with identical ideal dynamics are considered. Second, the leader has nonzero control input which is unknown to all the followers. In [17], [18] and [21]- [29], there exists no control input for the leader (i.e., the exosystem). In [15] and [16], all followers need to acquire the motion of the leader directly, but this assumption would be restrictive if the leader is a noncooperative target. Due to the heterogeneity of each agent, how to compensate for the leader's unknown input in a distributed form becomes more complicated in this paper. Third, the adaptive updating mechanism is applied to avoid the global information of the topology and the graph is directed. The constant gain approaches in [17], [18], [21] and [24] all rely on the eigenvalues of the Laplacian matrix. In [19], [30] and [31], the topology associated with the followers is undirected. Note that the Laplacian matrix of directed graph is asymmetric. There are complicated interrelations for the adaptive updating gains, the nonlinear functions to compensate for the unknown input of the leader, and the directed topology for the followers, which makes both the TVOF protocol design and the stability analysis in this paper more challenging than the case on undirected graph.

div.head: A. Basic graph theory
div.p: A directed graph can be described by G = {V, E}, where
stands for the node set, and E ⊆ V × V denotes the edge set between distinct nodes. An edge of the graph G is represented by
div.formula: ε ij = (v i , v j ) (i = j). The neighbor set of v i is defined as N i = {v j ∈ V : ε ji ∈ E}. Let W = [w ij ] ∈ R N ×N
div.p: denote the adjacency matrix associated with the graph G, where the weight w ij > 0 if and only if ε ji ∈ E, and w ij = 0 otherwise. The in-degree matrix of the graph G is defined as
div.formula: D = diag{ N j=1 w 1j , N j=1 w 2j , • • • , N j=1 w N j }.
div.p: The Laplacian matrix of the graph G is described by L = D -W. If there exists a root node which has directed paths to all other nodes in the directed graph G, then G is said to have a spanning tree.

div.head: B. Problem formulation
div.p: Consider a heterogeneous multi-agent system on a directed graph Ḡ with N followers and one leader. The dynamics of follower i
div.formula: (i ∈ {1, 2, • • • , N }) is described by ẋi (t) = A i x i (t) + B i u i (t) , y i (t) = C i x i (t) ,(1)
div.p: where x i (t) ∈ R ni is the state, u i (t) ∈ R mi is the control input, and y i (t) ∈ R p is the output of follower i. A i ∈ R ni×ni , B i ∈ R ni×mi and C i ∈ R p×ni are constant matrices with rank(B i ) = m i . The pairs (A i , B i ) are stabilizable, and the pairs (C i , A i ) are detectable. The leader is modeled as

where v 0 (t) ∈ R q is the state, r 0 (t) ∈ R l is the control input, and y 0 (t) ∈ R p is the output of the leader. S ∈ R q×q , E ∈ R q×l and F ∈ R p×q are constant known matrices. Assumption 1: The unknown control input of the leader r 0 (t) is bounded, and there exists a positive constant γ such that r 0 (t) γ. Remark 1: For practical robotic systems, the state of each agent that needs to achieve the desired formation includes position, velocity, orientation, and so on. For example, in the formation control of a group of quadrotor UAVs [17], only the position and velocity of each UAV are required to accomplish desired formations, and the attitude of each UAV can accommodate to external environment without keeping a strict formation. In this case, the output y i (t) (i ∈ {1, 2, • • • , N }) of each UAV is position and velocity, and the attitude can be included in the state x i (t). In [21]- [29], it is assumed that the exosystem has no control input, i.e., v0 (t) = Sv 0 (t). In order to generate more general reference signals and regulate the expected trajectory in real time, the leader is assumed to be nonautonomous with a nonzero input r 0 (t) in this paper. Furthermore, considering the case where the leader denotes a noncooperative target, it is assumed that r 0 (t) is unknown to all the followers, which is more general than r 0 (t) ≡ 0.
In order to specify the expected TVOF, a time-varying vector
div.formula: h o (t) = [h T o1 (t), h T o2 (t), • • • , h T oN (t)] T is introduced, where h oi (t) ∈ R p is piecewise continuously differentiable.
div.p: Definition 1: Consider the follower systems (1) and the leader system (2) on a directed graph Ḡ. For any bounded initial states, if
then the heterogeneous systems (1) and (2) accomplish the TVOF tracking.

Remark 2: From Definition 1, we can see that the outputs of the followers need to not only accomplish the desired formation but also track the trajectory generated by the leader. The time-varying vectors h oi (t) (i = 1, 2, • • • , N ) can describe both the formation configuration of the followers and the tracking relationship of the whole formation relative to the leader. The formation shape, orientation, and scale of the followers can be determined by choosing h oi (t) appropriately. Since the current paper focuses on how to design a distributed formation tracking protocol for a given output formation, h oi (t) is required to be predefined in this paper. If h oi (t) ≡ 0, the TVOF tracking problems can be reducible to the cooperative output regulation problems of heterogeneous multi-agent systems in [21]- [26].

div.head: Assumption 2:
div.p: The directed graph Ḡ has a spanning tree, where the leader is the root node.
Then, the Laplacian matrix L of Ḡ can be divided as
, where
div.formula: L 2 ∈ R N ×1 and L 1 ∈ R N ×N .
div.p: Lemma 1 ( [34]): Under Assumption 2, all eigenvalues of L 1 have positive real parts. Moreover, there exists a diagonal matrix
div.formula: D = diag {d 1 , d 2 , • • • , d N } with d i > 0 (i = 1, 2, • • • , N ) such that L1 = DL 1 + L T 1 D > 0.
div.p: Since the state of the leader is only available to a subset of followers, to acquire v 0 (t) for each follower, we will construct a distributed observer using the neighboring information interaction under the influences of the leader's unknown input. Moreover, the upper bound of r 0 (t) (i.e., γ) is global information, and a distributed observer for γ is needed. Let vi (t) and ηi (t) stand for the distributed estimations of v 0 (t) and γ for follower i
div.formula: (i ∈ {1, 2, • • • , N }), respectively.
div.p: Consider the following TVOF tracking protocol for follower
div.formula: i (i ∈ {1, 2, • • • , N }): vi (t) = Sv i (t) -αi (t) + ς T i (t)P ς i (t) P ς i (t) -(η i (t) + ρ) Ef i (t),(4-1)
ηi (t) = - 1 N j=0 w ij ksig β (η ei (t)) - N j=1 w ij ηj (t) ,(4-2)
ẋi (t) = A i xi (t) + B i u i (t) + L oi (C i xi (t) -y i (t)) , (4-3) u i (t) = K 1i (x i (t)-φ i (t))+K 2i vi (t)-(η i (t)+ρ) δ i (t) + τ i (t),(4-4)
div.p: where
div.formula: ς i (t) = w i0 (v i (t)-v 0 (t)) + N j=1 w ij (v i (t)-vj (t)) and ηei (t) = w i0 (η i (t) -γ) + N j=1 w ij (η i (t) -ηj (t))
div.p: denote the local errors of estimated values vi (t) and ηi (t) for follower i relative to its neighbors, respectively. In the distributed observer (4-1) for v 0 (t), αi (t) is the adaptive updating gain to avoid the global information of the graph, f i (t) represents the nonlinear function to suppress the leader's unknown input, ρ denotes any positive constant, and P ∈ R q×q stands for a positive definite matrix to be determined. In the distributed observer (4-2) for γ, k > 0 and 0 < β < 1 represent two positive constants. In the Luenberger state observer (4-3), xi (t) ∈ R ni is the estimation of x i (t), and L oi ∈ R ni×p represents a constant gain matrix. In the observer-based formation tracking controller (4-4),
div.formula: φ i (t) ∈ R ni satisfying h oi (t) = C i φ i (t)
div.p: is used to drive the outputs of followers to accomplish the expected formation specified by h o (t), δ i (t) ∈ R mi is applied to make up for the leader's unknown input, τ i (t) ∈ R mi is the formation compensation inputs, ρ is any positive constant, and K 1i ∈ R mi×ni and K 2i ∈ R mi×q are two constant gain matrices to be designed.
Assumption 3: The regulator equations
div.formula: X i S = A i X i + B i U i 0 = C i X i -F (5) have solution pairs (X i , U i ), i = 1, 2, • • • , N .
div.p: Assumption 4: The linear matrix equations
div.formula: B i R i -X i E = 0 (6) have solutions R i , i = 1, 2, • • • , N .
div.p: Remark 3: The regulator equations ( 5) are given in Assumption 3, whose solvability is a necessary condition to achieve output regulation ( [21]- [24] and [35]). Since the formation tracking controller (4-4) is constructed based on the output regulation theory, Assumption 3 is also a necessary condition to solve the formation tracking problems. Assumption 4 is similar to the matched condition used in the robust control with disturbances (see, e.g., [36] and [37]), which means that the unknown input of the leader r 0 (t) can be compensated by the control input u i (t) completely for each follower. Moreover, if all N + 1 agents have identical dynamics with A ∈ R n×n , B ∈ R n×m and C ∈ R p×n as the cases considered in [18], [19], [30] and [32], it can be verified that Assumptions 3 and 4 hold naturally with
div.formula: X i = R i = I n and U i = 0.
div.p: In light of rank(B i ) = m i , there is a nonsingular matrix
div.formula: Π i = [ BT i , BT i ] T with Bi ∈ R mi×ni and Bi ∈ R (ni-mi)×ni such that Bi B i = I mi and Bi B i = 0.
div.p: Algorithm 1: The TVOF tracking protocol (4) for follower i (i ∈ {1, 2, • • • , N }) can be designed by the following six steps.
Step 1. Consider a predefined TVOF specified by the vector
div.formula: h o (t) = [h T o1 (t), h T o2 (t), • • • , h T oN (t)] T . For φ i (t) satisfying h oi (t) = C i φ i (t)
div.p: , check the following formation tracking feasible condition:
div.formula: lim t→∞ ( Bi A i φ i (t) -Bi φi (t)) = 0.(7)
div.p: If there exist φ i (t
) such that the feasible condition (7) holds for each follower, then continue. Otherwise the given formation h o (t) is not feasible under the protocol (4) and the algorithm stops.
Step 2. Calculate the formation compensation input τ i (t) as follows:
div.formula: τ i (t) = -Bi (A i φ i (t) -φi (t)).(8)
div.p: Step 3. Choose X i , U i and R i such that the linear matrix equations ( 5) and ( 6) hold.
Step 4. L oi is chosen such that
div.formula: A i + L oi C i is Hurwitz, K 1i is selected to make A i + B i K 1i Hurwitz, and K 2i is designed as K 2i = U i -K 1i X i .
div.p: Solve the positive definite matrix Q i ∈ R ni×ni from the following Lyapunov equation:
div.formula: Q i (A i + B i K 1i ) + (A i + B i K 1i ) T Q i = -2I ni . (9
div.p: Step 5. To design the distributed observer (4-1) to get vi (t), solve P > 0 firstly from the algebraic Riccati equation (ARE)
div.formula: P S + S T P -P 2 + I q = 0. (10
div.p: Since (S, I q ) is controllable, there exists a unique solution P for the ARE (10). Then, the gain αi (t) is updated by the following adaptive law:
div.formula: αi (t) = ς T i (t)P 2 ς i (t),(11)
div.p: where αi (0) 0. The nonlinear function f i (t) is defined as
div.formula: f i (t) =      E T P ς i (t) E T P ς i (t) , E T P ς i (t) = 0, 0, E T P ς i (t) = 0. (12
div.p: Step 6. In (4-4), δ i (t) is defined as δ i (t) = R i g i (t) with g i (t) denoting the nonlinear function
div.formula: g i (t) =      H T i ξi (t) H T i ξi (t) , H T i ξi (t) = 0, 0, H T i ξi (t) = 0,(13)
div.p: where
div.formula: H i = Q i B i R i and ξi (t) = xi (t) -φ i (t) -X i vi (t).
div.p: Remark 4: It should be pointed out that not all timevarying formation vectors can be accomplished even for the homogeneous multi-agent systems (see, e.g., [18] and [19]). Considering the heterogeneous dynamics of each agent, the formation tracking feasible condition is proposed as (7), which implies that the given formations should be compatible with the dynamic constraints of the multi-agent systems. From (8), we see that the feasible formation set can be expanded by utilizing the compensation input τ i (t). More intuitive explanations on the physical meaning of the formation feasible constraint can refer to Illustrative Example 2 in [18].

Remark 5: To get a more direct form of the feasible condition (7), assume that rank (C i ) = p without loss of generality. Then, there is a nonsingular matrix T i = [ Ci , Ci ] with Ci ∈ R ni×p and Ci ∈ R ni×(ni-p) such that C i Ci = I p and C i Ci = 0 p×(ni-p) . Let h ōi (t) ∈ R ni-p denote any piecewise continuously differentiable column vector. Then,
div.formula: φ i (t) satisfying h oi (t) = C i φ i (t) can be rewritten as φ i (t) = T i [h T oi (t), h T ōi (t)] T = Ci h oi (t) + Ci h ōi (t)
div.p: . So the feasible condition (7) can be transformed to (14) where hoi (t) = Bi (A i Ci h oi (t) -Ci ḣoi (t)). Since the expected TVOF vector h oi (t) is predefined, we can calculate hoi (t) directly. Consider the following two cases. i) If lim t→∞ ( hoi (t)) = 0, then let h ōi (t) = 0. We can obtain that φ i (t) = Ci h oi (t) and the expected TVOF tracking is feasible. ii) If lim t→∞ ( hoi (t)) = 0, then check whether there exists h ōi (t) such that (14) holds. If there is such h ōi (t) for each follower, then let φ i (t) = Ci h oi (t) + Ci h ōi (t) and the given TVOF tracking is feasible. Otherwise h o (t) is infeasible under the protocol (4).
div.formula: lim t→∞ hoi (t) + Bi A i Ci h ōi (t) -Ci ḣōi (t) = 0,
div.p: Remark 6: Based on the neighboring estimation states, the distributed observer (4-1) is constructed for each follower to asymptotically estimate the leader's state. Different from the existing results in [21]- [24], there exists a nonlinear term (i.e., -(η i (t) + ρ) Ef i (t)) in (4-1), which is applied to suppress the influences of the unknown input of the leader in the distributed estimation level. Furthermore, in the observer-based controller , by using the formation information φ i (t), the local estimation state xi (t) and the distributed estimation state of the leader vi (t), the nonlinear term -(η i (t) + ρ) R i g i (t) is constructed by (13) to make up for the leader's unknown input in the formation control level.

Theorem 1: Suppose that Assumptions 1-4 hold. If the formation tracking feasible condition ( 7) is satisfied, the desired TVOF tracking is accomplished by the heterogeneous systems (1) and ( 2) with leader's unknown input under the distributed control protocol (4) determined by Algorithm 1.
Proof: In the following, we will prove that the distributed observers (4-1) and (4-2) are convergent firstly. Then, it is shown that the expected TVOF tracking can be realized.
Note that ηei (t)=

div.p: Thus, V ς (t) is bounded in [0, T η ), which implies that ς i (t) and αi (t) are bounded in [0, T η ). When t T η , we get that Π = 0. Then, it can be verified from (25) that

div.p: It holds from ( 27) that V ς (t) is bounded and so is αi (t).

Since αi (t) updated by (11) is monotonically increasing, it can be verified that αi (t) converges to certain positive constant [30]. Note that Vς (t) ≡ 0 leads to ς(t) = 0. Thus, it holds that lim t→∞ ς(t) = 0. Since L 1 is nonsingular, we have lim t→∞ ṽi (t) = 0, i.e., lim t→∞ (v i (t) -v 0 (t)) = 0.
Based on the convergence of the distributed observers (4-1) and (4-2), we will prove that the expected TVOF tracking can be realized under the proposed controller .

div.formula: (i = 1, 2, • • • , N ). Let e i (t) = y i (t) -h oi (t) -F v 0 (t) be the TVOF tracking error. Since h oi (t) -C i φ i (t) = 0 and C i X i -F = 0, we have lim t→∞ e i (t) = 0 (i = 1, 2, • • • , N ).
div.p: Therefore, the expected TVOF tracking is achieved by systems (1) and ( 2). This completes the proof of Theorem 1.

Remark 7: From the proof of Theorem 1, we can see that the unknown input of the leader has influences on the design of both the distributed observer (4-1) and the formation controller . Besides f i (t) in the distributed observer (4-1), we also need to construct an appropriate compensation term in the formation controller (4-4) for each follower using its local information. Note that we cannot obtain ξ i (t) directly for all the followers. Combining the estimation states vi (t), xi (t) and the formation information φ i (t), a novel compensation term -(η i (t) + ρ) δ i (t) is constructed in (4-4) to suppress r 0 (t) in the formation control level. Thus, only the output regulation strategy with r 0 (t) ≡ 0 in [21]- [29] cannot solve the TVOF tracking problems considered in this paper. Moreover, since the multi-agent system is homogeneous in [19], the influences of r 0 (t) can be compensated directly in the formation controller using the neighboring relative state. There is no need to construct a distributed robust observer and combine a compensation term with output regulation strategy in [19] for homogeneous case, which means that the TVOF tracking problems for heterogeneous multi-agent systems in this paper are more complicated than [19].

Remark 8: In light of the adaptive updating gain αi (t), the proposed observer (4-1) is distributed without needing any global information of the directed topology. Note that the existing approaches for undirected graph in [19], [30], [31] cannot be applied to solve the adaptive TVOF tracking problems on directed graph by a simple modification. Since the Laplacian matrix of directed graph is asymmetric, we have to construct a different adaptive TVOF tracking protocol and select an appropriate Lyapunov function for directed graph. Compared with the protocol for undirected graph in [19], there exist two distinct differences for the proposed distributed observer (4-1) in this paper. Firstly, we add a smooth function ς T i (t)P ς i (t) to αi (t) to accelerate the convergence of the estimation error and give extra freedom for stability analysis.

Secondly, we construct an extra distributed observer (4-2) to get γ for each follower using the neighboring interaction, so the complicated interrelations between the nonlinear functions to suppress r 0 (t) and the directed topology can be handled. Moreover, the Lyapunov function candidate (18) in this paper has a quite different and more complicated structure than the one in [19]. Therefore, both the TVOF tracking protocol design and the stability analysis on directed graph in this paper are more challenging than the case with undirected graph in [19]. Remark 9: Since the expected formation is time-varying in this paper, there exist both the formation information and its derivative in the design and analysis of the TVOF tracking protocol (4). Under the influences of the heterogeneous dynamics, the TVOF feasibility analysis and how to expand feasible formation set are new difficulties encountered in this paper, which have not been considered in the consensus or cooperative output regulation problems.

Since the nonlinear functions f i (t) and g i (t 12) and ( 13) are discontinuous, the TVOF tracking protocol (4) will cause chattering to the control input u i (t). In the following, we will replace f i (t) and g i (t) with continuous functions to avoid the large chattering of u i (t). The continuous nonlinear functions fi (t) and ḡi (t) are defined as
div.formula: fi (t) = E T P ς i (t) E T P ς i (t) + ε f i ,(34) ḡi
(t) = H T i ξi (t) H T i ξi (t) + ε gi ,(35)
div.p: where ε f i and ε gi are two small positive constants. Moreover, motivated by the σ-modification adaptive approach in [36], the adaptive law for αi (t) in ( 11) is redesigned as:
div.formula: αi (t) = -σ i αi (t) + ς T i (t)P 2 ς i (t),(36)
div.p: where αi (0) 0 and σ i denotes a positive constant. As shown in [36], the σ-modification adaptive law (36) has robustness to bounded noise. Theorem 2: Suppose that Assumptions 1-4 hold. Using the continuous functions fi (t), ḡi (t), and the σ-modification adaptive law (36) in the protocol (4), if the formation tracking feasible condition ( 7) is satisfied, then the TVOF tracking error e i (t) is uniformly ultimately bounded.

div.p: where µ is a positive constant. Let µ be sufficiently small such that µ < 1 2λmax(P ) and µ < 1 2 σ i (i = 1, 2, • • • , N ). Then, it holds that Vς (t) -µV ς (t) + .

According to the Comparison lemma in [34], it can be verified that V ς (t) (V ς (0) -/µ)e -µt + /µ. Thus, V ς (t) is ultimately bounded with the upper bound /µ, which implies that ς i (t) and αi (t) (i = 1, 2, • • • , N ) are ultimately bounded. Since ς(t) = (L 1 ⊗ I q )ṽ(t) and L 1 is nonsingular, we can obtain that ṽi (t) (i = 1, 2

Since ṽi (t) is ultimately bounded and lim t→∞ xi (t) = 0, we can obtain that ξi (t) and θi (t) are ultimately bounded. Note that lim t→∞ φi (t) = 0. According to the Comparison lemma in [34], it can be verified that V ξi (t) is ultimately bounded, which implies that e i (t) = C i ξ i (t) is ultimately bounded. This completes the proof of Theorem 2.

Remark 10: The continuous TVOF tracking protocol using fi (t) and ḡi (t) (i ∈ {1, 2, • • • , N }) can avoid the chattering of the control inputs effectively. From (43) and (44), we see that the TVOF tracking error e i (t) can converge to a small bounded set if the positive constants ε f i , ε gi , and σ i are selected to be relatively small. Moreover, as shown in [36], the σ-modification adaptive law (36) is robust to bounded noise.

div.head: IV. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: TVOF tracking problems for heterogeneous linear multiagent systems with a nonautonomous leader of unknown input were investigated. A TVOF tracking protocol composed of distributed observer and local formation controller was presented, where the distributed sliding mode observer can asymptotically estimate the state of the leader for each follower and the observer-based formation controller can drive the heterogeneous followers to realize the expected TVOF tracking under the influences of the leader's unknown input. To avoid the chattering and enhance robustness to noise, a continuous TVOF tracking protocol with σ-modification adaptive law was also proposed. Based on this result, it is interesting to further consider the TVOF tracking problems where not all the followers can obtain the leader's dynamic matrices directly. Moreover, how to add a cooperation term in (4-4) using neighboring relative output information of followers is an interesting topic for our future work.
